definitions.definition: to make pictures, or a picture of something, with a pencil, pen or chalk (but not paint)
definitions.labels: (US English)(US English)(US English)(especially British English)(North American English usually)(British English)(North American English)

examples.text: You draw beautifully.
to **draw a picture/map/diagram**
She drew a house.
a crudely drawn child's face
He drew a circle in the sand with a stick.

definitions.definition: to describe something in words in a way that produces an image in somebody's mind

examples.text: The report **drew a** grim **picture** of inefficiency and corruption.
She writes lively stories with sharply drawn characters.

definitions.definition: to have a particular idea after you have studied something or thought about it

examples.text: Is it possible to **draw inferences** about the environment during the Bronze Age?
What **conclusions** did you **draw** from the report?
We can draw some lessons for the future from this accident.

definitions.definition: to express a comparison or a contrast; to define the limits of something

examples.text: to **draw a comparison/a parallel/an analogy/a distinction** between two events
He attempted to draw a contrast between himself and the prime minister.
The site's boundaries were tightly drawn by the Department of the Environment.

definitions.definition: to produce a reaction or response

examples.text: The plan has **drawn** a lot of **criticism**.
The announcement drew loud applause from the audience.
The proposal has drawn interest from local businessmen.
The reforms drew widespread support from voters.

definitions.definition: to direct or attract somebody's attention to something

examples.text: Our aim is to **draw attention to** the plight of these children.
The exhibition drew great critical attention.
My eyes were drawn to the man in the corner.
Her gaze was drawn irresistibly to the scene outside.

definitions.definition: to attract somebody to come to a place or take part in an activity

examples.text: The movie is drawing large audiences.
The events continue to **draw** huge **crowds**.
The course draws students from all over the country.
Her screams drew passers-by to the scene.
We asked the surfing champion what first drew him to the sport.
Animals are instinctively drawn to those who like them.
He was increasingly drawn to the idea of making short films.

definitions.definition: to move in the direction mentioned

examples.text: The train drew into the station.
The train drew in.
The figures in the distance seemed to be drawing closer.
Their car **drew alongside** ours.
Her retirement is drawing near.
The meeting was **drawing to a close**.
As he drew near, I could see that he was limping.
as the boat drew towards the shore
He approached her but she drew away.

definitions.definition: to move something/somebody by pulling it or them gently

examples.text: He drew the cork out of the bottle.
I drew my chair up closer to the fire.
She drew me onto the balcony.
I tried to **draw him aside** *(= for example where I could talk to him privately)*.
She sat with her legs drawn up on the sofa.
The project enables students to draw together their knowledge, skills and experience.

definitions.definition: to pull a vehicle such as a carriage

examples.text: The King's coach was drawn by six horses.
a horse-drawn carriage

definitions.definition: to open or close curtains, etc.

examples.text: The blinds were drawn.
It was getting dark so I switched on the light and drew the curtains.
She drew back the curtains and let the sunlight in.

definitions.definition: to take out a weapon, such as a gun or a sword, in order to attack somebody

examples.text: She drew a revolver on me.
He came towards them with his sword drawn.

definitions.definition: to make somebody say more about something

examples.text: Spielberg refused to be drawn on his next movie.

definitions.definition: to decide something by picking cards, tickets or numbers by chance
definitions.sensetop: draw for somethingdraw somethingdraw something (from something)be drawn against somebody/somethingdraw somebody/something to do something

examples.text: We drew for partners.
He drew the winning ticket.
Names were drawn from a hat for the last few places.
Italy has been drawn against Spain in the first round.
Italy has been drawn to play Spain.

definitions.definition: to finish a game without either team winning

examples.text: England and France drew.
England and France drew 3–3.
England drew with/against France.
England drew their game against France.

definitions.definition: to take money or payments from a bank account or post office
definitions.sensetop: draw something out (of something)draw something (from something)draw something on something

examples.text: I drew out £200.
Can I draw $80 out of my account?
She went to the post office to draw her pension.
The cheque was drawn on his personal account.

definitions.definition: to take or pull liquid or gas from somewhere

examples.text: to draw water from a well
The device draws gas along the pipe.
The ducts draw out stale air.
The company has been drawing gas and oil out of the rich ground for 62 years.

definitions.definition: to breathe in smoke or air

examples.text: He drew thoughtfully on his pipe.
She breathed deeply, drawing in the fresh mountain air.

definitions.definition: if two people are at daggers drawn, they are very angry with each other
used to say that people or groups have shown which side they intend to support in an argument or contest that is going to begin
to aim carefully at somebody/something before shooting a gun

examples.text: One of the police officers drew a bead on the gunman and fired.

definitions.definition: to get no response or result

examples.text: So far, the police investigation has drawn a blank.

definitions.definition: to make somebody bleed
to stop doing something and rest

examples.text: She talks all the time and hardly stops to draw breath.
He spoke solidly for twenty minutes, barely pausing to draw breath.

definitions.definition: to live; to be alive

examples.text: He was as kind a man as ever drew breath.

definitions.definition: to make somebody direct their anger, criticism, etc. at you, so that others do not have to face it
to start being more careful in your behaviour, especially by spending less money than before

examples.text: Small businesses have had to pull their horns in during the recession.

definitions.definition: to refuse to do something; to set a limit

examples.text: I don't mind helping, but I draw the line at doing everything myself.
We would have liked to invite all our relatives, but you have to draw the line somewhere.

definitions.definition: to make a difference between two closely related ideas

examples.text: Where do you draw the line between genius and madness?

definitions.definition: to say that something is finished and not worth discussing any more

to use a method of choosing somebody/something that involves putting a number folded pieces of paper in a bag, one of them with a mark on it. People then take it in turns to take a piece of paper from the bag and the one who takes the paper with the mark on it is chosen.

examples.text: They drew lots for the right to go first.

definitions.definition: to be the person in a group who is chosen or forced to perform an unpleasant duty or task

examples.text: I drew the short straw and had to clean the toilets.

definitions.definition: to use a method of choosing somebody to do or have something in which each person takes a piece of paper, etc. from a container and the one whose paper has a special mark is chosen

examples.text: We drew straws for who went first.

definitions.definition: to stand straight and tall in order to show that you are determined, powerful or important

examples.text: He drew himself up to his full height and glared at us.

definitions.definition: (to establish) a clear limit to what you will do or accept

examples.text: It’s time to draw a line in the sand and stop allowing workplace bullying to continue.

definitions.definition: to speak to somebody in private, especially in order to warn or tell them about something

wordOrigin: Old English dragan, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch dragen and German tragen, also to draught.
